text: if you want to understand what's really
going on in the Middle East you need to
look at the forces that are at play
behind the scenes one of the ways of
looking in the Middle East is to think
of it as a giant chessboard where pieces
are constantly maneuvering around so who
are the losses in all of this and who
are the winners Iran has a huge interest
in what's going on in the Arab parts of
the Middle East and Iran of course is
not an Arab country but it's got a very
close ally in Lebanon in the form of
Hezbollah and also in the Syrian
government of President Bashar Assad
Iran came to his aid and helped reverse
the imminent defeat that he could well
have suffered at the hands of the rebels
a lot of the grounds that the rebels are
taken they were then beaten back out off
by Russian airstrikes backed by military
manpower on the ground Hezbollah and
other shear forces often under Iranian
command but working in concert with the
Syrians I think it's too early to say
that Syria's President Bashar al-assad
is a winner he hasn't lost Iran now has
a huge hand in the business the internal
politics and the security apparatuses
of Iraq Syria and Lebanon and that is
essentially given it a corridor of
influence all the way from the Afghan
border in the East to the Mediterranean
in the West and that's something that is
rattling Saudi Arabia and the Sunni Arab
Gulf states to the south so in all these
power struggles and conflicts that are
going on in the Middle East who's losing
out well strategically the Saudis they
may not want to admit it but they have
not come out well out of this big power
struggle with Iran to proxy militias
that they have supported in Syria have
not done well there on the backfoot
Isis so-called Islamic state is also a
loser
it's lost its caliphate they made a
strategic mistake in 2014 by
overreaching themselves one of the
really unfair things about big powers in
the Middle East whether they're Western
powers or whether they are regional
superpowers like Iran and Saudi Arabia
fighting these proxy wars is that the
losses alert those states themselves
it's the people caught up in the middle
and the most glaring example of this is
Yellin Iran's role in Yemen is limited
but they have been supplying weapons
they have been supplying ideological
doctrinal education to the rebels there
and the saudi-led coalition has
responded with a devastating air
campaign plus a blockade of ports and so
it's the Yemeni people who are suffering
there in Syria as other countries get
involved turkey Iran Russia the u.s. in
Syria it's the local people who've
suffered that country has been torn
apart and Iraq likewise it's always the
civilians who suffer
